content: Running Errands While Muslim What the post office, dry cleaner, and park are like for one mom and her daughters Amira Bennabi Kunbargi Blocked Unblock Follow Following Jun 9, 2018 Photo: Marcell Rafli/EyeEm/Getty Images Y ou shift the gear into park and push the buttons that open the automated sliding doors—a key feature you made sure to have when you bought the van three years earlier, because in a world measured by the ticks of the clock, the cumulative seconds add up. You hear the click of the seat belts, the crunch of disturbed leather, the swishing of arms and legs climbing over a mountain of seats, and the sweet rush of innocence longing to leap out into the world. You look into the rearview mirror and see three forces of nature. You tell the forces to stop, to wait for you. You run through the list in your head one more time: eggs, bread, toothpaste, paper towels, and mascara. You’ll stop at the shoe aisle if time allows. That reminds you: socks for the youngest. Black socks — they’ll keep longer and won’t show the mud stains. You have the list on your phone, but taking the device out of your bag will elicit the eyes of your daughters, and they will beg for it. You will dismiss their pleas or give in — either way, it’s a losing battle. Again you run through the list in your head and add black socks. You look out at the sea of empty shells glistening in the sun. Unrelieved rows of suburbia all parked neatly between the lines. Each shell has an owner, and you wonder who they are. You generalize. You are in a suburb of San Francisco, so you count yourself lucky. It’s liberal, diverse, educated — a recipe for tolerance. Because you want to be tolerated. Right? You’ll walk through the aisles with your most coveted worldly treasures riding in the cart, humming and chatting. You’ll fill your cart with what the store beckons you to need and then with what you actually need. You’ll smile, you’ll say excuse me, and you’ll hope they tolerate you. This is your sixth stop of the day. A store that sells everything to everyone. Everything to everyone and anyone is everyone. But today you don’t feel like an anyone or an everyone. You feel like a specific one. A red bull’s-eye meets your gaze. It surrounds you—on the scattered shopping carts, on a plastic bag blowing across the asphalt, and especially on the building in front of you. This should be your flagship store, you think. Your entity has become a bull’s-eye: a walking, talking target. You’ve been here a thousand times, but today you feel a certain affinity for this store. You’re still in the car. The steering wheel feels moist beneath your palms. You’re still in the car. You rewind your morning. Perhaps, between the lines of the livestream, you will discover why you’re still in the car. Photo: Jaymantri/Pexels / CC0 First stop The line is short at the post office. It’s still morning. You came here first to beat the early lunch rush. Your daughters look around at the thousands of metal boxes with keyholes. “Like email but in a real building,” you explain. You remember when your father explained email “like a post office but in an invisible building.” You become giddy at the revealed learning opportunity. You want them to see the world beyond its magical façade: the people, the work, the time, the space it takes to keep our status quo. It’s your turn. Your daughters inch up the counter to see what’s behind. The elderly woman smiles sweetly. “Good morning!” she says. You smile and reply in kind. You converse. She has a grandson who just graduated from college. The party is this weekend. She is excited; he is her first. She asks where you’re from. You oblige. You want to say Orange County, but you know that’s not what she means. She comments on the respectful mannerisms of your daughters. You look at them. They are beaming, and you wonder how much they have heard. Photo: freestocks.org/Pexels / CC0 Second stop You step into the bakery. The smell of melted chocolate delights your senses. You take it in; you feel warm. You look up and see a new sign behind the counter. It features the face of a young woman whose head is covered with a scarf. She looks like you. Beneath her face it reads, “Muslims are welcome here .” This is a good thing, you think. People in your neighborhood are taking a stand. They are supporting you. You get a funny feeling. You implore yourself to rejoice in the sign. The feeling doesn’t go away. Films and books are the only places you have seen or read of similar signs: “Coloreds welcome here” “No Japs” “Whites only” “Women not allowed” “Irish served here” “Jews not served” “No dogs, ******, Indians, or Mexicans” You add to the list, “Muslims are welcome here .” “Muslims are welcome here” is an answer, it seems, to a singular question: Are Muslims welcome here? The bakery’s answer: Yes! Muslims are welcome here. You wonder who responded differently. The post office? Never mind. It’s a public institution with ironclad laws against even hints at such questions (for now, at least). What about the coffee shop next door? You’re already salivating for that cup of dark brown heaven. Are you welcome there? What about the woman standing behind you in line? “Are Muslims welcome here?” you ask her telepathically. You read her body for answers: too cryptic. You order three double chocolate chip–macadamia nut cookies. You want to order four. The sweet aroma will suffice; it has zero calories. Photo: Elvert Barnes/Flickr / CC BY-SA 2.0 Third stop This time the smell hypnotizes you. You denied yourself the cookie and this is your reward. You wait in line patiently. You look like a daisy with three swaying petals. “Hold still. You’ll get your cookie as soon as we sit and Mama has her coffee,” you tell the petals. The line moves. You step forward and order the new usual: “Half-caff almond milk latte.” Photo: Brigitte Tohm/Pexels / CC0 You don’t need as much caffeine these days. There is other stimuli keeping you alert—so much so, you’re unable to sleep at night. You went to the naturopath to figure out what’s wrong. She discovered you’re allergic to milk. You’re used to childhood staples disappearing from your life, so you start drinking almond milk. After a while, you get used to the cardboard taste. You’re used to the stares, but you always notice that lurking glare, usually one in a crowd. Lately you are seeing it more frequently. The symphony of whistles and tremors blares from behind the counter as you follow the composition of your cup. You look around at the obscure crowd and feel the stinging sonder. You consciously smile to the masses, hoping for connection in this fleeting juncture. A few stares meet your smile. You’re used to the stares, but you always notice that lurking glare, usually one in a crowd. Lately you are seeing it more frequently. You lie to yourself, tell yourself it’s only in your mind, convince yourself that you’re projecting the rising angst — until the hate passes from the eyes into the mouths of those who glare. Another crack on your enameled heart. A version of your name is called. The hot cup is warm in your hand. You take the first sip, and for a moment, you forget everything. The tug on your flowing shirt brings you back. “Oh, yes, the cookies!” They’ve been so patient. You must be doing something right. You sit outside under the shade of an umbrella table. Cookies and giggles: a childhood staple. You count your blessings. The morning is crisp and bright; the air feels glorious. You count your blessings. No loud or sudden noises. You count your blessings. Safe to have a routine. You count your blessings. You think of your distant relatives — light-years away — you shiver, and you count your blessings. Photo: Jim Green/Getty Images Fourth stop You park in front of the dry cleaner. It’s only three steps away from the door and another three steps to the register counter. Six steps total. Five, seven, nine: the ages of your generally well-behaved progeny. “It’ll only be a minute!” You pause. You can’t leave them. You already draw attention to yourself. What if someone sees them? What if this someone calls the police? What if you get investigated? What if they get placed into foster care? Perhaps they look for reasons to have three fewer humans raised in your hijacked faith. You’ve heard the stories. It’s too risky. You take them with you. The chemical stench burns your nostrils. Your girls pinch their noses, and you tell them it’s rude. They stop. You smile at the woman behind the counter. She takes your bag, counts the items, and, in a heavy accent, curtly tells you what you owe. You don’t blame her. Perhaps it’s hard to smile while constantly breathing in putrid chemicals. She takes a moment to look at your daughters. She smiles; it’s hard not to. When she looks back at you, the smile fades. She hands you the ticket. You take it, say thank you, and leave. Photo: Aaron Burden / Unsplash Fifth stop You stop at the park for a quick ride on the swings. You already promised. You run after your daughters and come in fourth place. “Watch me, Mama, watch me!” You stand behind grinning and watching and beaming. A woman to your right pushes her young daughter. A man to your left stands behind his son. The woman turns in your direction and comments on your five-year-old. “She’s so cute!” You thank her, but she looks past you — because a thing does not speak. She continues, now clearly addressing the man on your left, “How old is she?” The man looks confused. “She’s not mine.” You make eye contact with the woman. “She’s five,” you reply. You want her to see your face. The resemblance to your daughter is marked—if the woman takes a moment to see past her judgment. You look back at your girls. You’ve wilted. “Five more minutes!” you call. You want to leave. Photo: rawpixel / Unsplash Sixth stop “A target at Target!” You make up the jingle in your mind. You’ll cast a woman wearing a red-and-white bull’s-eye scarf around her head. It’ll be comical. You wonder how much you could sell it for. Your inner chuckle fades into a sullen sigh. You’ve gotten used to the nagging in your stomach. It has become a background noise; you almost forget it’s there. Until you freeze. At first you don’t know why. You rewind. You review. It becomes clear. If scientists could measure the speed of mind and memory — perhaps they can; you’re not sure — you wonder what the chronometer would read. You look at the clock. Only 30 seconds have passed since you’ve parked. You’re still in the car. You look at the buttons that open and close the automated sliding doors to the outside world. You look at your daughters, who are waiting to jump out. You push the buttons and close the doors. You’ve had enough of the world today. Let’s go home. Home. Home Home is a hearth, a haven, an abode, a birthplace, at harmony with surroundings, a place where a human lives. You seek home only to discover it’s been bulldozed. Although it retains its roof, its decorated halls and polished furniture, its quirky knickknacks, and the etched-in memories in its familiar walls, you find yourself homeless. It began with a word here and a war there. The words turned into rants, the rants became a ban, and now you don’t know if and where it will end. And so the homelessness grows. You’ll have to run errands again tomorrow, you remind yourself. You wonder how much more of your home will disappear by the time you arrive back to your house the next time you step out into this America. Your America has been wrenched, and you wonder if it was ever really yours.
title_html: Running Errands While Muslim
html:
Homepage
Homepage
Sign inGet started
  • Body
  • Mind
  • Heart
  • Hands
  • Eyes
  • Soul
  • About

Running Errands While Muslim

What the post office, dry cleaner, and park are like for one mom and her daughters

Amira Bennabi Kunbargi
Jun 9, 2018

You shift the gear into park and push the buttons that open the automated sliding doors—a key feature you made sure to have when you bought the van three years earlier, because in a world measured by the ticks of the clock, the cumulative seconds add up.

You hear the click of the seat belts, the crunch of disturbed leather, the swishing of arms and legs climbing over a mountain of seats, and the sweet rush of innocence longing to leap out into the world. You look into the rearview mirror and see three forces of nature. You tell the forces to stop, to wait for you.

You run through the list in your head one more time: eggs, bread, toothpaste, paper towels, and mascara. You’ll stop at the shoe aisle if time allows. That reminds you: socks for the youngest. Black socks — they’ll keep longer and won’t show the mud stains.

You have the list on your phone, but taking the device out of your bag will elicit the eyes of your daughters, and they will beg for it. You will dismiss their pleas or give in — either way, it’s a losing battle. Again you run through the list in your head and add black socks.

You look out at the sea of empty shells glistening in the sun. Unrelieved rows of suburbia all parked neatly between the lines. Each shell has an owner, and you wonder who they are. You generalize. You are in a suburb of San Francisco, so you count yourself lucky. It’s liberal, diverse, educated — a recipe for tolerance.

Because you want to be tolerated. Right?

You’ll walk through the aisles with your most coveted worldly treasures riding in the cart, humming and chatting. You’ll fill your cart with what the store beckons you to need and then with what you actually need. You’ll smile, you’ll say excuse me, and you’ll hope they tolerate you.

This is your sixth stop of the day. A store that sells everything to everyone. Everything to everyone and anyone is everyone. But today you don’t feel like an anyone or an everyone. You feel like a specific one.

A red bull’s-eye meets your gaze. It surrounds you—on the scattered shopping carts, on a plastic bag blowing across the asphalt, and especially on the building in front of you. This should be your flagship store, you think. Your entity has become a bull’s-eye: a walking, talking target. You’ve been here a thousand times, but today you feel a certain affinity for this store.

You’re still in the car.

The steering wheel feels moist beneath your palms.

You’re still in the car.

You rewind your morning. Perhaps, between the lines of the livestream, you will discover why you’re still in the car.

First stop

The line is short at the post office. It’s still morning. You came here first to beat the early lunch rush. Your daughters look around at the thousands of metal boxes with keyholes.

“Like email but in a real building,” you explain.

You remember when your father explained email “like a post office but in an invisible building.” You become giddy at the revealed learning opportunity. You want them to see the world beyond its magical façade: the people, the work, the time, the space it takes to keep our status quo.

It’s your turn. Your daughters inch up the counter to see what’s behind. The elderly woman smiles sweetly.

“Good morning!” she says.

You smile and reply in kind. You converse. She has a grandson who just graduated from college. The party is this weekend. She is excited; he is her first. She asks where you’re from. You oblige. You want to say Orange County, but you know that’s not what she means.

She comments on the respectful mannerisms of your daughters. You look at them. They are beaming, and you wonder how much they have heard.

Second stop

You step into the bakery. The smell of melted chocolate delights your senses. You take it in; you feel warm. You look up and see a new sign behind the counter. It features the face of a young woman whose head is covered with a scarf. She looks like you. Beneath her face it reads, “Muslims are welcome here.”

This is a good thing, you think. People in your neighborhood are taking a stand. They are supporting you. You get a funny feeling. You implore yourself to rejoice in the sign. The feeling doesn’t go away.

Films and books are the only places you have seen or read of similar signs:

“Coloreds welcome here”

“No Japs”

“Whites only”

“Women not allowed”

“Irish served here”

“Jews not served”

“No dogs, ******, Indians, or Mexicans”

You add to the list, “Muslims are welcome here.”

“Muslims are welcome here” is an answer, it seems, to a singular question: Are Muslims welcome here?

The bakery’s answer: Yes! Muslims are welcome here. You wonder who responded differently.

The post office? Never mind. It’s a public institution with ironclad laws against even hints at such questions (for now, at least).

What about the coffee shop next door? You’re already salivating for that cup of dark brown heaven. Are you welcome there? What about the woman standing behind you in line?

“Are Muslims welcome here?” you ask her telepathically. You read her body for answers: too cryptic.

You order three double chocolate chip–macadamia nut cookies. You want to order four. The sweet aroma will suffice; it has zero calories.

Third stop

This time the smell hypnotizes you. You denied yourself the cookie and this is your reward. You wait in line patiently. You look like a daisy with three swaying petals.

“Hold still. You’ll get your cookie as soon as we sit and Mama has her coffee,” you tell the petals.

The line moves. You step forward and order the new usual: “Half-caff almond milk latte.”

You don’t need as much caffeine these days. There is other stimuli keeping you alert—so much so, you’re unable to sleep at night. You went to the naturopath to figure out what’s wrong. She discovered you’re allergic to milk. You’re used to childhood staples disappearing from your life, so you start drinking almond milk. After a while, you get used to the cardboard taste.

You’re used to the stares, but you always notice that lurking glare, usually one in a crowd. Lately you are seeing it more frequently.

The symphony of whistles and tremors blares from behind the counter as you follow the composition of your cup. You look around at the obscure crowd and feel the stinging sonder. You consciously smile to the masses, hoping for connection in this fleeting juncture. A few stares meet your smile. You’re used to the stares, but you always notice that lurking glare, usually one in a crowd. Lately you are seeing it more frequently.

You lie to yourself, tell yourself it’s only in your mind, convince yourself that you’re projecting the rising angst — until the hate passes from the eyes into the mouths of those who glare. Another crack on your enameled heart.

A version of your name is called. The hot cup is warm in your hand. You take the first sip, and for a moment, you forget everything. The tug on your flowing shirt brings you back.

“Oh, yes, the cookies!”

They’ve been so patient. You must be doing something right. You sit outside under the shade of an umbrella table. Cookies and giggles: a childhood staple. You count your blessings. The morning is crisp and bright; the air feels glorious. You count your blessings. No loud or sudden noises. You count your blessings. Safe to have a routine. You count your blessings. You think of your distant relatives — light-years away — you shiver, and you count your blessings.

Fourth stop

You park in front of the dry cleaner. It’s only three steps away from the door and another three steps to the register counter. Six steps total. Five, seven, nine: the ages of your generally well-behaved progeny.

“It’ll only be a minute!”

You pause. You can’t leave them. You already draw attention to yourself. What if someone sees them? What if this someone calls the police? What if you get investigated? What if they get placed into foster care? Perhaps they look for reasons to have three fewer humans raised in your hijacked faith. You’ve heard the stories. It’s too risky. You take them with you.

The chemical stench burns your nostrils. Your girls pinch their noses, and you tell them it’s rude. They stop. You smile at the woman behind the counter. She takes your bag, counts the items, and, in a heavy accent, curtly tells you what you owe.

You don’t blame her. Perhaps it’s hard to smile while constantly breathing in putrid chemicals. She takes a moment to look at your daughters. She smiles; it’s hard not to. When she looks back at you, the smile fades. She hands you the ticket. You take it, say thank you, and leave.

Fifth stop

You stop at the park for a quick ride on the swings. You already promised. You run after your daughters and come in fourth place.

“Watch me, Mama, watch me!” You stand behind grinning and watching and beaming.

A woman to your right pushes her young daughter. A man to your left stands behind his son.

The woman turns in your direction and comments on your five-year-old. “She’s so cute!”

You thank her, but she looks past you — because a thing does not speak. She continues, now clearly addressing the man on your left, “How old is she?”

The man looks confused. “She’s not mine.”

You make eye contact with the woman. “She’s five,” you reply.

You want her to see your face. The resemblance to your daughter is marked—if the woman takes a moment to see past her judgment. You look back at your girls. You’ve wilted.

“Five more minutes!” you call. You want to leave.

Sixth stop

“A target at Target!” You make up the jingle in your mind. You’ll cast a woman wearing a red-and-white bull’s-eye scarf around her head. It’ll be comical. You wonder how much you could sell it for.

Your inner chuckle fades into a sullen sigh. You’ve gotten used to the nagging in your stomach. It has become a background noise; you almost forget it’s there. Until you freeze. At first you don’t know why. You rewind. You review. It becomes clear.

If scientists could measure the speed of mind and memory — perhaps they can; you’re not sure — you wonder what the chronometer would read. You look at the clock. Only 30 seconds have passed since you’ve parked.

You’re still in the car.

You look at the buttons that open and close the automated sliding doors to the outside world. You look at your daughters, who are waiting to jump out. You push the buttons and close the doors.

You’ve had enough of the world today. Let’s go home.

Home.

Home

Home is a hearth, a haven, an abode, a birthplace, at harmony with surroundings, a place where a human lives.

You seek home only to discover it’s been bulldozed. Although it retains its roof, its decorated halls and polished furniture, its quirky knickknacks, and the etched-in memories in its familiar walls, you find yourself homeless.

It began with a word here and a war there. The words turned into rants, the rants became a ban, and now you don’t know if and where it will end. And so the homelessness grows.

You’ll have to run errands again tomorrow, you remind yourself. You wonder how much more of your home will disappear by the time you arrive back to your house the next time you step out into this America.

Your America has been wrenched, and you wonder if it was ever really yours.

  • Politics
  • Parenting
  • Religion
  • Equality
  • Eyes

  • Amira Bennabi Kunbargi

    Medium member since Mar 2018

    Writing to humanize the demonized.

  • Human Parts

    What it means to be

    • Human Parts
    What it means to be
title: Running Errands While Muslim
content_html:
Running Errands While Muslim

What the post office, dry cleaner, and park are like for one mom and her daughters

Amira Bennabi Kunbargi
Jun 9, 2018

You stop at the park for a quick ride on the swings. You already promised. You run after your daughters and come in fourth place.

“Watch me, Mama, watch me!” You stand behind grinning and watching and beaming.

A woman to your right pushes her young daughter. A man to your left stands behind his son.

The woman turns in your direction and comments on your five-year-old. “She’s so cute!”

You thank her, but she looks past you — because a thing does not speak. She continues, now clearly addressing the man on your left, “How old is she?”

The man looks confused. “She’s not mine.”

You make eye contact with the woman. “She’s five,” you reply.

You want her to see your face. The resemblance to your daughter is marked—if the woman takes a moment to see past her judgment. You look back at your girls. You’ve wilted.

“Five more minutes!” you call. You want to leave.

Sixth stop

“A target at Target!” You make up the jingle in your mind. You’ll cast a woman wearing a red-and-white bull’s-eye scarf around her head. It’ll be comical. You wonder how much you could sell it for.

Your inner chuckle fades into a sullen sigh. You’ve gotten used to the nagging in your stomach. It has become a background noise; you almost forget it’s there. Until you freeze. At first you don’t know why. You rewind. You review. It becomes clear.

If scientists could measure the speed of mind and memory — perhaps they can; you’re not sure — you wonder what the chronometer would read. You look at the clock. Only 30 seconds have passed since you’ve parked.

You’re still in the car.

You look at the buttons that open and close the automated sliding doors to the outside world. You look at your daughters, who are waiting to jump out. You push the buttons and close the doors.

You’ve had enough of the world today. Let’s go home.

Home.

Home

Home is a hearth, a haven, an abode, a birthplace, at harmony with surroundings, a place where a human lives.

You seek home only to discover it’s been bulldozed. Although it retains its roof, its decorated halls and polished furniture, its quirky knickknacks, and the etched-in memories in its familiar walls, you find yourself homeless.

It began with a word here and a war there. The words turned into rants, the rants became a ban, and now you don’t know if and where it will end. And so the homelessness grows.

You’ll have to run errands again tomorrow, you remind yourself. You wonder how much more of your home will disappear by the time you arrive back to your house the next time you step out into this America.

Your America has been wrenched, and you wonder if it was ever really yours.
